msgs.text: What is the governance of Bitcoin? How do things get changed/updated? How are things decided?

Bitcoin governance isn't clearly defined, and this is actually a strength of the protocol, not a weakness. [ Talk about BIP process ]. It is an extremely conservative and meticulous process. Bitcoin isn't easy to change at all, and that is a good thing! Because Bitcoin is software, it is flexible and malleable. But for those same reasons, the devs need to be extremely careful with updates. Everything needs to be carefully tested over an extended period of time. Bitcoin has a peer-to-peer, anarchic network governance (Pierre Rochard).

The decentralization of governance is what makes Bitcoin incorruptible from a network perspective. Nothing could change for the rest of time, and Bitcoin would still do what it does as long as there is still one node in the network. - <@671364216086855720>

The Bitcoin Network does not rely on any single intermediary or authority outside itself to function. Arguably, there are many competing intermediaries, but Bitcoin incentives them to compete with each other by cooperating to support Bitcoin.
